video.title: HTML Full Course - Build a Website Tutorial
video.description:
Learn the basics of HTML5 and web development in this awesome course for beginners. 

Want more from Mike? He's starting a coding RPG/Bootcamp - https://simulator.dev/

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:54) Choosing a Text Editor
⌨️ (0:08:13) Creating an HTML file
⌨️ (0:20:31) Basic Tags
⌨️ (0:36:47) Comments
⌨️ (0:42:13) Style & Color
⌨️ (0:48:07) Formatting a Page
⌨️ (0:59:16) Links
⌨️ (1:07:33) Images
⌨️ (1:16:12) Videos & Youtube iFrames
⌨️ (1:23:00) Lists
⌨️ (1:28:53) Tables
⌨️ (1:37:21) Divs & Spans
⌨️ (1:44:54) Input & Forms
⌨️ (1:53:44) iFrames
⌨️ (1:57:21) Meta Tags

Course developed by Mike Dane. Check out his YouTube channel for more great programming courses: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvmINlrza7JHB1zkIOuXEbw

🐦Follow Mike on Twitter - https://twitter.com/mike_dane

🔗The Mike's website: https://www.mikedane.com/

⭐️Other full courses by Mike Dane on our channel ⭐️
💻Python: https://youtu.be/rfscVS0vtbw
💻C: https://youtu.be/KJgsSFOSQv0
💻C++: https://youtu.be/vLnPwxZdW4Y
💻SQL: https://youtu.be/HXV3zeQKqGY
💻Ruby: https://youtu.be/t_ispmWmdjY
💻PHP: https://youtu.be/OK_JCtrrv-c
💻C#: https://youtu.be/GhQdlIFylQ8

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

I would move on to CSS and learn it together with HTML.

 For HTML, focus a lot of time on learning div, forms, lists, and spans. 

For CSS, focus a lot of time on learning Grid and responsive design because there are billions of people around the world who browse on their phones.

topLevelComment.author: Snowflake001
topLevelComment.text: Should I learn w this tutorial or get a newer tutorial? Are there much changes? I enjoy his teaching tho

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
The tutorial is still relevant as oppa Mike is using HTML version 5. 

Learn HTML and CSS together as they go hand-in-hand. The former is the easiest while the latter is the most challenging yet the most rewarding because it makes your website beautiful by adding font styles, colors, shapes, photos, etc.; you're the best Hollywood plastic surgeon! Afterward, learn Javascript. It adds behavior to your website which CSS can't do. Behavior as in interactivity; if you move your mouse cursor to a photo of Belle Delphine, that photo will change to a photo of The Rock. Or if you move the cursor to a line of text, that text will change to a 100px font size and have a pink background with alice blue text. 

JS will be the most difficult to learn because it involves programming. The holy trinity of web development - HTML, CSS, and Javascript. 

For HTML, focus a lot of time on learning div, forms, lists, and spans. 

For CSS, focus a lot of time on learning Grid and responsive design because there are billions of people around the world who browse on their phones.

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
Yes, the HTML here is enough. What you should be prioritizing is learning CSS. 

Learn HTML and CSS together as they go hand-in-hand. The former is the easiest while the latter is the most challenging yet the most rewarding because it makes your website beautiful by adding font styles, colors, shapes, photos, etc.; you're the best Hollywood plastic surgeon! Afterward, learn Javascript. It adds behavior to your website which CSS can't do. Behavior as in interactivity; if you move your mouse cursor to a photo of Belle Delphine, that photo will change to a photo of The Rock. Or if you move the cursor to a line of text, that text will change to a 100px font size and have a pink background with alice blue text. 

JS will be the most difficult to learn because it involves programming. The holy trinity of web development - HTML, CSS, and Javascript. 

For HTML, focus a lot of time on learning div, forms, lists, and spans. 

For CSS, focus a lot of time on learning Grid and responsive design because there are billions of people around the world who browse on their phones.

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
Learn HTML and CSS together as they go hand-in-hand. The former is the easiest while the latter is the most challenging yet the most rewarding because it makes your website beautiful by adding font styles, colors, shapes, photos, etc.; you're the best Hollywood plastic surgeon! Afterward, learn Javascript. It adds behavior to your website which CSS can't do. Behavior as in interactivity; if you move your mouse cursor to a photo of Belle Delphine, that photo will change to a photo of The Rock. Or if you move the cursor to a line of text, that text will change to a 100px font size and have a pink background with alice blue text. 

JS will be the most difficult to learn because it involves programming. However, you can still be successful just being focused on HTML and CSS. There are demos of devs who have made some pretty hot websites without JS. HTML and CSS are enough to make stylish websites as I have seen some really great ones, but it all depends on your CSS skills. 

For HTML, focus a lot of time on learning div, forms, lists, and spans. 

For CSS, focus a lot of time on learning Grid and responsive design because there are billions of people around the world who browse on their phones. 

All the best!

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
I think your file path may be wrong or you spelt color as colour; search how to write CSS file path addresses. In the gist of it, the CSS file has to have the correct file path address relative to the location of the HTML file. *For simplicity:* 1. Name the CSS file as styles.css 2. Copy and paste the CSS file into the same folder as the HTML file. 3. In the HTML file, write the following inside the element: Now let's find out if it works: *Copy and paste the following in the HTML file:* My Website!

Belle Delphine!

*Copy and paste the following in the CSS file:* h1 { color: pink; background: red; } Save all files and everything should work.

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
Learn HTML and CSS together as they go hand-in-hand. The former is the easiest while the latter is the most challenging yet the most rewarding because it makes your website beautiful; you're the best Hollywood plastic surgeon! Afterward, learn Javascript. It adds behavior to your website like an image disappearing when you hover the mouse cursor over it. 

JS will be the most difficult to learn because it involves programming. However, you can still be successful just being focused on HTML and CSS. There are demos of devs who have made some pretty hot websites without JS. 

For HTML, focus a lot of time on learning forms, div, span, and lists. 

For CSS, focus a lot of time on learning Grid and media queries.

topLevelComment.text: how did u claculate the aspect ratio of the image of cat?

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
01:13:45 Right-click the image file and click Properties. The default aspect ratio will be listed there. You can alternatively calculate the ratio by your own educated guess. However, resizing images ought to be done in CSS. Mike just showed him resizing in the HTML itself for a quick illustration example, but such things are done in CSS 99% by everyone. 

If you're serious about learning HTML, learn CSS. It's mandatory because it adds beauty to the HTML. Learn HTML and CSS together.

If you're curious, Atom is good as well as Brackets which I use. Notepad is bland and there are no autofill or helpful features like in Brackets. I recommend Notepad because the UI is simple and writing HTML with no autofill will help your muscle memory. 

When you think you have gained some experience, move on to a better editor.

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
Yes, that's called in-line styling, but this is bad practice as 99% of devs use external styling because debugging is easier and, most importantly, it allows you to reuse CSS by just conveniently linking the CSS file to your HTML file. 

Your boot camp will cover this. All the best!

This is a paragraph

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
Hey, are you getting Elden Ring? Both methods are right, but the first example with the spaces is conventional and easier on the eyes. I have written thousands of lines of code and have included spaces and comments of where tags end:

blahblah

blahblah

Imagine if you have tons of things you write inside your p tags. You would have to scroll up and down to check where tags end. Having those comments help a lot especially if it comes to debugging. If you don't see a comment on a particular tag, you will likely know you didn't close it.

topLevelComment.author: Trent Clarkson
topLevelComment.text: Is anyone else having trouble displaying videos? I tried his methods, but only a blank space was created on my website where the video was supposed to be. Even with the "controls" attribute, the video box appeared with all the settings, but there was no video displayed. I found that I needed to use <source> tags within the <video> container tags: <video><source src="" type="video/mp4"></source></video>. While it's great to have a solution, I want to know why this didn't work in case I encounter related problems in the future.

I don't know what I was really getting at but for anyone wanting to learn web design or any programming language all I can say is "Just jump right in, learn, listen, practice and over time it'll grow on you almost like breathing, it's just subconsciously instilled in the back of your mind, lol."

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
Practice HTML by making a couple of more websites. Then, learn CSS. CSS makes your HTML website pretty by adding font styles, colors, shapes, photos, etc. Commit a lot of time learning CSS. 

Finally, learn Javascript which is the most difficult because it's a programming language. It adds behavior to your website which CSS can't do. Behavior as in interactivity; if you move your mouse cursor to a photo of Belle Delphine, that photo will change to a photo of The Rock. Or if you move the cursor to a line of text, that text will change to a 100px font size and turn red. 

You don't have to learn Javascript. HTML and CSS are enough to make stylish websites, but it all depends on your CSS skills.

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
HTML isn't programming. It's a markup language (Hypertext Markup Language). Learning any language will be challenging. It it helps, HTML is easy to learn. I recommend you to focus more on HTML forms and tables. 

Practice HTML by making a couple of more websites. Then, learn CSS. CSS makes your HTML website pretty by adding font styles, colors, shapes, photos, etc. Commit a lot of time learning CSS. 

Finally, learn Javascript which is the most difficult because it's a programming language. It adds behavior to your website which CSS can't do. Behavior as in interactivity; if you move your mouse cursor to a photo of Belle Delphine, that photo will change to a photo of The Rock. Or if you move the cursor to a line of text, that text will change to a 100px font size and turn red. 

You don't have to learn Javascript. HTML and CSS are enough to make stylish websites, but it all depends on your CSS skills.

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text:
How much time to be good at HTML, CSS, or JS depends on the time you devote to learning each day. We are all different in absorbing new material so I don't know the real length, but let's say after you read this comment you decide to play Dark Souls 3 for two hours. Those two hours could have been spent learning and practicing HTML. Now you're two hours 'behind' your goal. Not playing the blame game here, I have my days of being burned out so I just go and play Overwatch for three hours, but imagine how much more I could have learned about web development by increasing my knowledge by 5%, 10%, or even just 1% within those three hours. Does this mean you should always study and never relax by gaming or watching Netflix? No. Everyone needs rest. Just try not to take advantage of your rest time by gaming ten hours a day and studying for five minutes. 

I recommend you to learn how to create forms and inputs.HTML is pretty easy to learn. Take your time learning CSS because it's tricky; learn CSS Grid. JS will be the most difficult.

Coming back to my roots and going back to basics just to see how far I'm come (I'm like 33yr old currently) but looking back I'm like tripping out how simple simple It is. It just feels natural. I don't know what I was really getting at but for anyone wanting to learn web design or any programming language all I can say is "Just jump right in, learn, listen, practice and over time it'll grow on you almost like breathing, it's just subconsciously instilled in the back of your mind, lol."

replies.author: funhole26
replies.text: @EthanS Question...how do i link to a subsection of my site. Example... i want to have three headings at the top that when pressed bring you down to that appropriate portion of the website. Thanks for all your videos! Its helped supplament my fcc journey!

replies.author: funhole26
replies.text: @EthanS Hey, thanks for the explanation and offering up future advice. Much appreciated!

replies.author: EthanS
replies.text: Good questions! Later in development, the head tag holds a LOT of information regarding the webpage (behaviors, information, search engine stuff). For now you may not want to worry TOO much about it as a lot of the visual aspects are not there. You can think of the main tag as a way to section your webpage. Inside the main tag is the MAIN content of the page. Lemme know if you have more questions!

topLevelComment.author: MrRivethead1001
topLevelComment.text: I can always tell when a customer uses Word, Wordpad, or other large/full function text editors is that they commonly add hidden special characters to the file. For example if I have a customer edit a Linux file and they do it in Windows using Word, if Notepad++ is used to examine the file with show hidden characters turned on, you can see quite a bit of fluff added into the file. So yes, when writing raw code, it's always best to use the KISS method (Keep It Simple Stupid).

topLevelComment.author: N. Pemola Devi
topLevelComment.text:
Pokémon,[a][1][2][3] also known as Pocket Monsters[b] in Japan, is a Japanese media franchise managed by The Pokémon Company, a company founded by Nintendo, Game Freak, and Creatures. The franchise was created by Satoshi Tajiri in 1995,[4] and is centered on fictional creatures called "Pokémon", which humans, known as Pokémon Trainers, catch and train to battle each other for sport. Works within the franchise are set in the Pokémon universe. The English slogan for the franchise is "Gotta Catch 'Em All".[5][6]

The franchise began as Pocket Monsters Red and Green (later released outside of Japan as Pokémon Red and Blue), a pair of video games for the original Game Boy handheld system that were developed by Game Freak and published by Nintendo in February 1996. It soon became a media mix franchise adapted into various different media.[7] Pokémon has since become the highest-grossing media franchise of all time,[8][9][10] with $90 billion in total franchise revenue.[11][12] The original video game series is the second-best-selling video game franchise (behind Nintendo's Mario franchise)[13] with more than 368 million copies sold[14] and one billion mobile downloads,[15] and it spawned a hit anime television series that has become the most successful video game adaptation[16] with over 20 seasons and 1,000 episodes in 169 countries.[14] In addition, the Pokémon franchise includes the world's top-selling toy brand,[17] the top-selling trading card game[18] with over 30.4 billion cards sold,[14] an anime film series, a live-action film, books, manga comics, music, merchandise, and a theme park. The franchise is also represented in other Nintendo media, such as the Super Smash Bros. series, where various Pokemon characters are playable.

In November 2005, 4Kids Entertainment, which had managed the non-game related licensing of Pokémon, announced that it had agreed not to renew the Pokémon representation agreement. The Pokémon Company International oversees all Pokémon licensing outside Asia.[19] In 2006, the franchise celebrated its tenth anniversary.[20] In 2016, the Pokémon Company celebrated Pokémon's 20th anniversary by airing an ad during Super Bowl 50 in January and re-releasing the first Pokémon video games 1996 Game Boy games Pokémon Red, Green (only in Japan), and Blue, and the 1998 Game Boy Color game Pokémon Yellow for the Nintendo 3DS on February 26, 2016.[21][22] The mobile augmented reality game Pokémon Go was released in July 2016.[23] The first live-action film in the franchise, Pokémon Detective Pikachu, based on the 2018 Nintendo 3DS spin-off game Detective Pikachu, was released in 2019.[8]

The most recently released core series games, Pokémon Sword and Shield, were released worldwide on the Nintendo Switch on November 15, 2019.[24] Pokémon is celebrating its 25th anniversary in 2021, teasing a very special celebration.[25]

topLevelComment.author: Maliha Ahmed
topLevelComment.text:
Well since I'm home and bored, I will teach myself how to make a website using this video! I'll edit my comment after I finish this tutorial and tell you if I successfully made a website or not! Wish me luck x.



[edit: After working on this part by part throughout the week, I can successfully do the basics. He explained each element very well and also told us why each element is necessary, making it much easier to understand. One issue I faced was when I wanted to link the page 3 (located in a separate folder within the website folder) back to the index page and page 2. Which took me a while to do because he only explained half of it, which is understandable because there was a lot to cover. But apart from that, the tutorial overall is very simple and super easy to comprehend, even for absolute beginners (like myself). I am able to make a basic website from scratch, but I do need some more practice as I have to refer back to this video wherever I forget how to write a piece of code. Now I shall go and watch his CSS tutorials so I can make a real website! Thank you for following this journey!]

replies.author: Kandowa Tech
replies.text: Hello Syed, for you to be able to edit and upload the client website, you need to have access to their hosting account. you need to be able to have access to their website file, as you probably know by now a website is just a bunch of files linked together. so you need to be able to have access to those files for you to edit them and then once you're done working on them you need to have access to their hosting account for you to be able to upload those files. I hope this was helpful. And if you're interested in learning HTML, CSS, and javascript, I run a channel where I upload tutorials on HTML, CSS, and javascript. If that's something that interests you, then please visit my channel, I got a lot of tutorials to choose from and I believe they will help you. 40:50 Comment is just for your backup. Suppose you collect a bunch of data and write it inside a code and then you realise that I dont need this now, but I can use this later. So either deleting the code and writing the code again just put the older code inside the comment and copy the code so that you can use it later on.

The best purpose of writing comment is suppose you have a very difficult  or lengthy code at last, so you can do it first to decrease some pressure, and just put it inside the comment. And when you need it copy the code remove the comment an boom :)

topLevelComment.author: Unnamed
topLevelComment.text: HTML IS NOT CREATING WEBSITE.

replies.author: i removed my balls with an angle grinder
replies.text:
HTML is the structure of a website. You can also learn a few other languages that will help you build a website; JavaScript, PHP, and CSS.

With JavaScript you can add programs to your website that the user can interact with

PHP is a bit more advanced. You can use this language to create databases for your website to work around. You can use this language to fetch information from stuff that isn't on your website such as another file on your PC.

CSS makes your website look better by changing the colours, font, and text size, position, etc.

topLevelComment.text:
Quick tip for ppl running linux + firefox:
Look up supported video formats, .ogg and .webm (using vp9) have native support with html
If you're using .webm and want to autoplay you need to write ' muted ' for it to autoplay
Example <video src="video.webm" autoplay loop muted></video>

I had problems with this step so I thought maybe someone else will too.

topLevelComment.text:
I recommend (as a beginner), start using a text editor as sublime text or atom, it will help you to start with more confident. I use "atom" and really recommend it, atom uses different colors to help you identify each part of your code, and the best part is that it also autocomplete words, for ex. you only need to write "p", atom will autocomplete:

, it saves a lot of time and help you to focus on the really important part.

replies.author: Mostafa Kamar
replies.text:
the charset meta defines the types of characters you will use on your web page, by that I mean : with the UTF-8 charset your site can be friendly with other languages like Arabic , thus if we chose another charset it will not show the characters as it was written.
generally use UTF-8 as it's very popular and is use in every major website.

Sir please let me know why should programmers use apple macbook 
Not a gaming or other high processor laptops

replies.author: MineData
replies.text:
Security & quality - Macs are said to be safer against malware, viruses, and other types of malicious attacks.

Unix command line - macOS operating system has been built on top of Unix, which is the command-line that powers a huge part of the world's filesystems and servers.

Development Environment - MacOS has a native UNIX environment, which is used by a majority of web servers. And it’s an obviously better idea to code on a machine that runs on the same environment.

Cross-platform compatibility - When being a Macbook owner, you can easily run all the main operating systems, which is a big plus for people that learn programming.

Hardware Quality - Developers are likely to say that the Apple’s force touch trackpad is a luxury they would never leave.

Credit: Hackernoon

topLevelComment.text:
Today (April 1st 2020) is my first day learning the skills of web development. By the end of this month, I hope to understand HTML, CSS, and have my feet wet in JavaScript. By the end of the year, I hope to have enough of a grasp on JavaScript that I can learn React. After React, I'll learn what I need to learn for the projects I'm working on. By this time next year (April 1st 2021), I hope to have the basic skills necessary to create projects for my friends, family, and local businesses. Then, I will freelance a bit. By January 2022, I hope to have the necessary skills, experience, and projects in my portfolio to land a full time job. Deep breathe in...and...release...

Here we go.

replies.author: xqkcq628
replies.text: @ibn Kazbek You have to use JS in front-end. Python is for back-end. You can use javascript in back--end with frameworks, but you cant use python in front-end. Learn both of them, then you can decide what language you want  to use for back-end. Once you understand the concept of programming, it is so easy to learn another language and both python and javascript are easy languages to learn. So if you want to learn web desing and its  your first priority go with JS as it is both used for front-end and back-end with frameworks, then learn python and its frameworks.

replies.author: Abid Bari
replies.text: @ibn Kazbek You can use python but you need to learn a web dev framework like Django. topLevelComment.author: B
topLevelComment.text: I started with one of those content mgmt deals and watched one of your vids to help me build my site there during the free trial. I was impressed with your teaching an d persona. When I finished my website, I learned how much it would cost me for the ugly inflexible site I would have and said, No way. I purchased  HTML & CSS  by Jon Duckett, which has over a thousand positive reviews. I got through the html part and was starting the css section. I got stuck on something and looking on Utube, I found the CSS for beginners series. I was amazed at how cool my mock website was looking in only a week of learning. The padding and borders with 3-D effects are midnight to high noon compared to the content mgmt crap I almost bought, and this is just less than a month since I bought the text books. ....I was up to around lesson 50 in CSS for beginners. Good teacher he is. I was starting to get lost at that point. Partly because I wasn't just using his example and copy pasting. I was following his basic outline and typing the code myself. I figured it would be a better way to learn. But I was getting to the point where some things weren't working, such as using a mailbox image for when I hover over a certain button. I'm also having a hard time with terminology. Names of people, places and things has been a serious weak point for me since childhood and ive usually been able to fake my way through things, However, with this, I am finding terminology extremely important to follow along with both book and vid. So, I decided to go back to lesson 1 of CSS. I think I know pretty much enough to build the simple website I need to sell the books I write if I refer to the book or vids when I get stuck ( I also have the matching Java script and query text book by the same author). But, ya know what? Learning this, while challenging, really is fun. It's cool to hit that refresh button after writing some code and seeing what I made. I've already made a page much cooler looking than anything I've seen on the web. I've linked a couple pages I made and also linked to my word press site I've made a audio and video player pages and a form with drop down choices for a customer as well as a link to an email client from the book. I am wondering how connecting to a payment method and a way for customers to download my eBooks is going to work. So, I want to learn more. Much more. And I want to learn the basics better and have a real firm grasp of HTML before returning to CSS and dabling in Java and possibly Query ( I have no idea what they involve yet)  I'm glad I stumbled upon this tutorial because right off you stressed terminology and so far you are explaining it well. I feel confident when I finish this, I will be much better prepared to go back to CSS. Thanks in advance and I'll comment again as we progress. WolfMan.

topLevelComment.author: The boring programmer
topLevelComment.text:
Tip for good image Width-Height ratio:


Let's say your picture is 680x510 (width=680, height=510.) What you'll do is look for the difference between the two numbers. You can do (bigger number) - (smaller number), which gives us a difference of 170 in this case. Then, you substract both Width and Height with the difference (680 - 170, 510 - 170). You do this as many times as you want until you get the image size you want.

replies.text: @swallowedinthesea11 yes i made sure the photo was in the same folder as the html file. I'll do what you said there thanks i'll let you know if it works

replies.author: swallowedinthesea11
replies.text: You likely have typed the path in your src incorrectly. Is your photo in the same directory (folder) as your HTML file? And tip: never use the URL address in your image's src because it could be broken; if not now, then later. Instead, right-click the photo, click  *Save image as...*, and use it to store photos in your PC.

replies.author: Bagasl
replies.text:
@The Krispreme my English is bad, but I'll try to explain.
There are 2 ways: find hosting and upload your site on it or write your own server.

The first option is simple.
Second is simple too if you have some skills

For server you need:
1. Public IP address, usually it costs some money, in my case it's free. Contact your ISP.
2. The server on which your site will run. You can write it on Golang in a few lines of code. Google it.
3. Setup port forwarding on your router. From 80 to the port your server is listening to.
4. Visit freenom and choose any suitable domain, configure DNS for your public IP.

Done

replies.author: Wired Technology
replies.text:
*Long* Yes, perhaps for the rest of 2019-2021 and no afterwards. The reason for this is, as the world is constantly changing there will be new ways of writing HTML with many deprecations...And this goes for all mark-up/programming languages. As a developer, you'd have to keep up with the things that might be new, and I don't recommend staying in the old-fashioned way.

*Short* I mean what we are learning here is HTML5 which is the current updated version of HTML. Eventually, it would be updated and if that does happen then you should go learn whatever's new.
